title: COVID-19 pandemic in the United States
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic in the United States is part of the worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Since January 2020, 49,051,140[5] confirmed cases have been reported with 788,202[5] deaths, the most of any country, and the nineteenth-highest per capita worldwide.[8] As many infections have gone undetected, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimated that, as of May 2021, there could be a total 120.2 million infections in the United States, or more than a third of the total population.[9][6] COVID-19 is the deadliest pandemic in U.S. history;[10] it was the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. in 2020, behind heart disease and cancer.[11] From 2019 to 2020, U.S. life expectancy dropped by 3 years for Hispanic Americans, 2.9 years for African Americans, and 1.2 years for white Americans.[12] These effects have persisted as U.S. deaths due to COVID-19 in 2021 exceeded those in 2020.[13]
